To the grove 'tis in vain I repair,</br>'Tis not theirs one gay charm to impart;</br>They afford not a refuge from care,</br>Or give ease to a love-stricken heart.
To the streams, on whose banks I reclin'd,</br>I must now bid a lasting adieu,</br>Since, by bringing the past to my mind,</br>They the cause of my sorrows renew.
Both the dance and the song I avoid,</br>For they cannot remove my despair;</br>Those pleasures I might have enjoy'd,</br>Had my Florimel's form been less fair.
But felicity once was my  lot,</br>Gay pleasure encircled me round;</br>Than a palace more bless'd was my cot,</br>There peace and content might be found.
In the dance I then mov'd with delight,</br>I then could be joyous and gay,</br>Soft repose was my portion each night,</br>And chearfulness welcom'd the day.
Health spread her soft tinge o'er my cheek,</br>My limbs with fresh vigour were strung,</br>With indiff'rence of love I could speak,</br>And in years, as in sorrow, was young.
I have sat on the bench at my door,</br>With a pleasure to monarchs unknown,</br>For I was not dependant, though poor,</br>And my flocks, tho' but few, were my own.
But why of my flocks should I sing,</br>Of my bench, or my cottage so neat!</br>For, had I the wealth of a king,</br>I would lay it at Florimel's feet.
But, alas!  like a fond, foolish swain,</br>To the winds I my sorrows relate;</br>Then, since she regards not my pain,</br>Let me learn to submit to my fate.</br>
